awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Physical processes in formation and breakdown of hypoxia in a tropical bay
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is to study hypoxia in a tropical embayment in Panama (Bahia del Amirante) using a combination of ongoing monitoring data, new observations, and a numerical model. The project will focus on physical processes unique to tropical systems. Hypoxia, whereby marine waters become severely depleted in oxygen content, is a widespread deleterious anthropogenic influence on estuarine and coastal waters and is increasing in coastal regions globally. Hypoxia in tropical marine systems is poorly understood and understudied, despite the important implications for tropical ecosystems which sustain important fisheries habitats and coastal biodiversity. The project will include a field campaign to observe the physical and chemical parameters of the Bay as well as a modeling component to simulate the dynamic and biogeochemical responses and interpret the observational data. The project is expected to provide new understanding of the dynamics that initiate and control hypoxia in tropical systems. The results of this project will be disseminated through presentations at scientific meetings, seminars at universities, public talks, websites, and peer-reviewed journal articles. Communication of results to the broader scientific community will include a workshop on "Understanding hypoxia in the Caribbean" to be held in Panama in the third year of the grant. This workshop will bring together researchers from throughout the Caribbean working on diverse hypoxic systems with local Panamanian researchers and other stakeholders.

This project includes an observational campaign and numerical simulations that will address the dynamics of hypoxia in shallow tropical systems. Physical and chemical measurements are designed to identify the important physical processes throughout the evolution of a seasonal hypoxic event in the Bay. Bahia Almirante is a tropical embayment in the Bocas del Toro region of Panama that has experienced repeated, seasonal hypoxia resulting in widespread bleaching and mortality of corals and other invertebrates. A fully-coupled physical biogeochemical model will be developed for the bay to test the dynamical understanding. The project will also leverage a historical record of weekly observations (temperature, salinity and oxygen) by the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute (STRI) since 2010 to give historical context to our observations and to provide validation for the simulations. The physical processes regulating the ventilation of low-oxygen bottom waters in temperature coastal regions include inflow of fresh water and atmospheric fluxes, which affect density stratification, advection, and wind, wave, and tidal-driven turbulent mixing. A better understanding of the physical mechanisms and environmental conditions responsible for oxygen variability in tropical bays will yield rich insight into benthic ecology, turbulent mixing, larval connectivity, coastal hypoxia, ocean acidification and cross-shelf exchange of nutrients, pollutants, hypoxic waters.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Hypoxia is one of the most widespread deleterious anthropogenic influences on estuarine and coastal waters globally, but is primarily reported and studied in temperate coastal waters and estuaries. Relatively little work has been done in shallow tropical waters, despite the important implications for tropical ecosystems which sustain important fisheries habitats and coastal biodiversity. The overarching objective for the project was to address this knowledge gap: developing a predictive understanding of the dynamical processes that determine the magnitude and duration of hypoxia events and thermal inversions in shallow, tropical bays. Specific objectives include: (1) Determining the physical and chemical processes that contribute to initiation of hypoxic conditions in shallow, tropical bays, and (2) Resolving the processes that lead to hypoxia breakdown along with the associated timescales and spatial variability for these processes. 

 

To achieve the project goals outlined above, we carried out an observational campaign in Bahia Almirante, a tropical embayment in the Bocas del Toro region of Panama that has experienced repeated, seasonal hypoxia causing widespread bleaching and mortality of corals and other invertebrates. The observations included a suite of physical and chemical measurements designed to identify the important physical processes throughout the evolution of a seasonal hypoxic event in the bay. We are developed a realistic hydrodynamic model of the bay and surroundings to test our dynamical understanding of these events.  In the future this model can be expanded to incorporate a fully coupled biogeochemical model to examine the nitrogen and oxygen dynamics. 

 

In addition to these measurements, we leveraged a historical record of weekly spatial sampling (temperature, salinity and oxygen) collected by the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute to provide historical context to our observations and to provide validation for our numerical simulations.  Analysis of the observational data indicates that hypoxia in Bahia Almirante is related to seasonal increases in stratification driving the isolation of bottom bay waters from oxygen sources (atmosphere and open ocean). In addition, data showed a close correlation between hypoxia and thermal inversions that occur as a result of radiative heating.  Hypoxic conditions in Bahia Almirante are relieved episodically when higher oxygen ocean water that is denser than the back bay enters Bahia Almirante through channels between the islands.  The work described here has provided the basis for a PhD thesis for A. Adelson and has been published or is soon to be submitted to peer-reviewed journals (Adelson et al., 2022; Adelson et al, in prep).

 

This work has expanded beyond what was originally proposed in multiple ways.  First, an extensive bathymetric mapping study was undertaken by partners at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute to provide high-resolution bathymetry of Bahía Almirante (the methods and bathymetry from this work have been presented at conferences by Panamanian researcher, Ximena Boza).  Second, the relationship between physical and chemical parameters of water quality in coastal rivers and its relation to land cover was outlined in a manuscript published in Frontiers in Water(Clark et al. 2022).  Third, we used existing large scale model output (HYCOM) to understand the mesoscale processes influencing coastal circulation in and around Bahia Almirante which in turn, control the renewal of bottom waters within the bay.  In a manuscript soon to be published in the Journal of Physical Oceanography, we show how, westward-propagating Caribbean Current eddies modify circulation in the western Caribbean Sea, influencing Panama-Colombia Gyre and coastal currents near Bahia Almirante. This work was led by a postdoctoral scholar supported by the project, Dr. Sam Kastner, who is now an assistant professor at Western Washington University. 

 

To communicate the results of this work we organized a one-day symposium entitled “Linking Environmental Conditions Across the Landscapes and Seascapes of Bahia Almirante to Biodiversity and Human Well-Being” in Panama City, Panama which featured PIs, students, technicians, and post-docs.  Presentations covered different aspects of Bahia Almirante, many related to the hypoxia in the bay and it’s impacts on the reef environment.  The symposium, held complex in Panama City was open to the public and widely advertised around the local universities, NGOs and relevant government departments.  Talks were in English or Spanish with simultaneous translation.  Six Bocas del Toro community leaders traveled to Panama City with support from this grant to participate in the stakeholder discussion at the end of the day. Over the following three days, the PIs and collaborators on these projects met in a workshop format to write a synthesis review paper using the Press-Pulse Dynamics model as a framework to describe the interactions between the land, the climate, the bay and the people of Bahia Almirante which has been submitted to  Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science.
